title: Don G. Despain
text:
Dr. Don Gardner Despain (born 1940) is an American <a href="botanist">botanist</a>, plant <a href="ecologist">ecologist</a> and fire behavior specialist, who specialized in the <a href="flora">flora</a> of <a href="Yellowstone%20National%20Park">Yellowstone National Park</a>.
Biography.
Despain was born in 1940 in <a href="Lovell%2C%20Wyoming">Lovell, Wyoming</a>, the oldest of five children to Daniel Gordon Despain and Lillian Gardner. He attended <a href="Lovell%20High%20School">Lovell High School</a> and then studied at the <a href="University%20of%20Wyoming">University of Wyoming</a>, receiving a B.S. in Botany in 1966. He did graduate work at the <a href="University%20of%20Arizona">University of Arizona</a>, receiving an M.S. in plant ecology in 1967, and then a PhD in Plant Ecology from the <a href="University%20of%20Alberta">University of Alberta</a> in <a href="Edmonton">Edmonton</a>, Alberta, Canada in 1971.
In the mid 1980s, he was the President of the Wyoming Native Plant Society, and Vice-president for the Biological Section at the Montana Academy of Science. From 1998 to 1999, he was vice-president of the scientific research society <a href="Sigma%20Xi">Sigma Xi</a> from 1998 to 1999, and President from 1999 to 2001.
From 1971 to 2006, he was a research <a href="biologist">biologist</a> with the <a href="National%20Park%20Service">National Park Service</a> in Yellowstone National Park, and was instrumental in generating the fire management plans in use by the park since 1972. He generated a vegetation map of the park and did extensive research in fire behavior, fire effects and landscape factors in fire spread. He also worked as an ecologist with the <a href="U.S.%20Geological%20Survey">U.S. Geological Survey</a>, testing the utility of remote sensing systems for vegetation and fuels appraisal.
Despain retired in 2006, although he is still active in scientific research. He lives in <a href="Bozeman%2C%20Montana">Bozeman, Montana</a>.
